Hi Scott,Sorry about the diagnosis but aren't you glad that you got it out!!  Welcome to the cancer club.  :-/Funny you should ask about the diabetes and thyroid link.  Of the five girls in my family who had their thyroids removed three of us now have Type II diabetes and the other two are pre-diabetic.  My mother has horrible thyroid problems and is diabetic.  My daughter had her thyroid removed (Hashimoto's and precancer) and she is hypoglycemic.I have been doing a little research about the thyroid and diabetes link and there is a lot of literature on it.  Here's just a few of the articles:http://journal.diabetes.org/clinicaldiabetes/v18n12000/Pg38.htmhttp://www.diabetes.ca/Section_About/thyroid.asphttp://www.thyroidtoday.com/PatientResources/english/Thyroid%20Hormone_E09.pdfNot all thyroid patients will develop diabetes but it is something that we should all be mindful of and watching for.  Be watchful for putting on excess weight around your middle, frequent thirst, frequent hunger, frequent urination, the feeling of "bottoming out" or feeling "drunk" after eating.  It's something that you might want to discuss with your endo (maybe he/she could run an A1C and see where you are at right now).Hang in there!!

That was a good question.  Diabetes runs in my family(mom and several brothers have it)and my mom a thryroid disorder (don't know what kind cause she passed  away over 20 years ago) and one of my five sisters had part of her thyroid removed.  I'll have to ask my endo to watch out for diabetes for me.   As much as I love sweets and love to bake, getting diabetes on top of thyroid cancer would really bite!!
It's a blood test that shows your average glucose control over the past few months.  It's a vital blood test for diabetics.http://www.labtestsonline.org/understanding/analytes/a1c/test.html

question: Hello all,  just received the path report and good and bad news.Lets start off with the bad news.Instead of 1 nodule(original was left side) they found a second on the right side and the same type of cancer.  Papillary.OK, the good news:Left side was a whopping 0.8 CM and the right side they found was a whole 0.2 cm.  I was shocked to find out about the right side and am glade the surgeon decided to remove the entire thyroid once he found out the left side was cancerous.  He didn't know of the right side until he received the path report.  Also good was that all surgical margins were free of the tumor so it stayed where it was at and did not spread.So now I wait until I see my endo to tell me what is next.I was started on 100mg synthroid and have not felt any problems since the surgery.  SO I think I am running pretty normal because I feel the same as I did before the surgery just a little winded due to the surgery if I do too much since it was only 1 week ago.Question, when someone gets a TT done what are the chances of getting diabetes?  I have not heard or read anything about this as will ask my endo once I see him.  Is this something normal?  I am only 38 and male and hope this does not happen!!!!  Is there any literature about this?Thanks everyone out there!Scott
title: Path report back after TT
